subj-group.subject: Toward a Better Understanding of State and Local Public Finance Instruments: Efficiency and Implications

title-group.article-title: LOCAL SALES TAX, CROSS-BORDER SHOPPING, AND DISTANCE

abstract.p: This paper, using Nebraska sales tax data, estimates the magnitude of cross-border shopping in response to distance when a local sales tax changes. First, I test the hypothesis that consumers do not have an incentive to cross a city border to shop when a tax changes. Then, I specify the elasticity of a local sales tax as the function of distance. The results demonstrate that a one percent point increase in a local sales tax would create cross-border shopping at the border by 10-14 %; 3-5% in a city that is 20 miles away from other cities (i.e. shopping areas). The results also suggest that the influence of cross-border shopping would virtually disappear in a city that is more than 31 - 38 miles away from other cities.
